Brown Memorial Church Minister Chooses 'How Is Right
Determined' As Topic
CITES CODE OF ETHICS
Present Generation's Cosmopolitanism Prevents Dogmatization, He Says
In speaking on "How is Right
Determined?" before the University Supper Club last Tuesday
night, T. G. Speers, minister of
Brown Memorial Church, declared
that in the search for right, three
fundamental principles of morality
must be followed.
Gives Morality Principles

"First, take advantage of the best
moral and ethical intuition of the
past; that is, profit by the experiments of our predecessors in the
matter of conventions," he said.
"Second, be honest with yourself.
Men are not likely to do evil when
it is plainly labeled 'evil,' but they
are prone to rationalize and disguise it as some action having wellfounded reasons to back it. Third,
do not look for a hard and fast
code of ethics, but find some comprehensive morality principles that
are applicable everywhere. Respect
for personality is the fulfilling of
the law."
Dogmatizing on the codes of
morality is impossible today, the
minister asserted, because of the
present generation's close association with other peoples. He gave
the wide-spread views on marriage,
birth-control as indications of this
association.

MEET WITH WILLARD
Trustees Head Will Recommend Move for Abandonment of Project at Meeting
In an attempt to persuade the
Johns Hopkins Board of Trustees
to abandon its plans to sell a portion of the Homewood campus to
private interests, twelve professors
of Hopkins conferred with Daniel
Willard, president of the Board
early this week.
The professors, headed by Broadus Mitchell, associate professor of
economics, contended that the action of the board was unwise in offering for sale a 331' plot of land
northwest of the athletic field and
bounded by University Parkway
and Wyman's Park Drive.
Cites Cases at Other Colleges
They declared that other universities which had shown similar lack
of foresight in planning their campuses were later forced to buy land
at doubled prices to accommodate
their buildings. They also complained, it was learned, that the
University was being hemmed in
by apartment houses and pointed
out that the probable purchase of
the land for the construction of
such buildings would aggravate the
situation.

Denying the assertion made by
numerous students on the campus
that the Johns Hopkins University
Student Council has no jurisdiction
to suspend those who have been absent from weekly assemblies once,
Francis C. Warlow, president of
the organization, declared:
Assemblies Hopkins Tradition

"It is a University tradition that
there will be weekly assemblies.
That assemblies be held is not a
constitutional regulation of the Student Council. The Hopkins has set
the time for them, and there are
supposed to be no freshmen or
sophomore classes at 11.30 A. M.
each Thursday.
"Because the Council is the voice
of the student body, it has been
given the job of presiding at and
arranging programs for the assemblies.
Duty To Enforce Attendance

"As a consequence, it is the duty
of the Student Council to enforce
regular attendance each Thursday.
It is untrue that the organization
does not have power to suspend
those students who have been absent
for only one assembly.
"No definite number of absences
have been set, and no definite provisions have been made for suspensions."

Los Angeles.—Two University
of Southern California students will
sail on March 28 to compete in
Honolulu's second international
oratorical contest on April 3 and
will join the University of Hawaii
speakers in opposing a team from
six Tokio universities in a debate
which will be held sometime between April 3 and April 10.
The oratorical contest will find
the best speakers entered from six
Tokio universities, the University
of Hawaii and the University of
Southern California. Five speakers from five different Japanese
universities, including Keio, Waseda and Meiji will compete in the
contest. The subject for the orations has not been definitely determined, but, according to tentative
plans submitted by W. B. Beck,
faculty advisor at Hawaii, the
speakers will be permitted to base
their orations on any specific subject, provided it has some bearing
on education or on Pacific problems.

Representatives from circles in
36 U. S. colleges, mostly of the
Southern States, attended the recent Omicron Delta Kappa Convention which was held in Lexington, Kentucky, Thursday, Friday,
and Saturday, March 5, 6, 7.
Dr. McVey, president of the University of Kentucky, welcomed the
delegates and entertained them at
tea on Friday, afternoon. Business
sessions were held on Friday and
Saturday, at which reports from
the various circles were submitted.
The visitors were very well entertained in the fraternity houses
on the university campus. A dinner-dance was held Friday evening,
the co-eds from K. U. attending.
Edwin Lockard, Hopkins circle
representative, will publish a complete report at a later date.
